title: 111_s3323
content: The "Federal Contracting Oversight and Reform Act of 2010" defines appropriate congressional committees and amends the reporting requirements under the Clean Contracting Act of 2008. The Clean Contracting Act of 2008 is amended to include a self-reporting requirement for federal contracts exceeding the simplified acquisition threshold or $500,000. The Clean Contracting Act of 2008 now requires contractors to certify information submission for contracts over $500,000 or have total federal contracts below $10,000,000. The Inspector General of each Federal agency must conduct periodic inspections or reviews of contract files. The Clean Contracting Act of 2008 mandates agencies to inspect contract files for compliance with database information and report findings to Congress annually. The Clean Contracting Act of 2008 requires agencies to annually report to Congress on contractors listed on the Excluded Parties List System who received federal contracts or waivers for suspension or debarment. SEC. 5. CONSOLIDATION OF CONTRACTING INFORMATION DATABASES. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Administrator of General Services, must submit a plan to integrate and consolidate various contracting information databases into a single searchable network within one year of this Act's enactment. This network will include databases such as the Excluded Parties List System (EPLS), Central Contractor Registry (CCR), Contractor Performance Assessment Reporting System (CPARS), Federal Assistance Award Data System (FAADS), and Federal Awardee Performance and Integrity Information System (FAPIIS). The plan aims to integrate and consolidate various contracting information databases into a single searchable network within one year of the Act's enactment. This network will include databases such as FAPIIS, FBO, FPDS-NG, PPIRS, and USAspending.gov. SEC. 6. The Inspector General of the General Services Administration will study the use of identifying numbers for Federal contractors to determine if the current system is effective and explore the feasibility of a new identification system. A report on the study must be submitted to congressional committees within 180 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 7. DATABASE SCOPE amended Section 872(c) of the Clean Contracting Act of 2008 to extend the period to 10 years. Changes were made to administrative proceedings and acknowledgments of fault.
